articles.headline: Fatah and Hamas Announce Outline of Deal
articles.snippet: Fatah and Hamas, rival Palestinian movements, announced an agreement in principle to end the years-long internal schism.
articles.abstract: Fatah and Hamas, rival Palestinian movements, announced an agreement in principle to end the years-long internal schism.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The two main Palestinian factions, Fatah and Hamas, announced Wednesday that they were putting aside years of bitter rivalry to create an interim unity government and hold elections within a year, a surprise move that promised to reshape the diplomatic landscape of the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Bernanke Defends Fed’s Role in Running Economy
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke argued that the bank was doing all it could to increase employment without risking higher inflation.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke argued that the bank was doing all it could to increase employment without risking higher inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Wednesday conducted the first scheduled press conference in the central bank’s history, sitting behind a mahogany desk as cameras clicked and flashed. Mr. Bernanke explained his management of the economy in the calm, patient and serious manner of the college professor that he used to be.

articles.headline: With Document, Obama Seeks to End ‘Birther’ Issue
articles.snippet: The president’s move injected him into the “birther” controversy in the hope of finally ending it, as aides said, or perhaps even turning it to his advantage.
articles.abstract: The president’s move injected him into the “birther” controversy in the hope of finally ending it, as aides said, or perhaps even turning it to his advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama released his long-form birth certificate on Wednesday, a step that injected him directly into the simmering “birther” controversy in the hope of finally ending it, or even turning it to his advantage.

articles.headline: Camera Whimsy on iPhones
articles.snippet: A cellphone is obviously not the best camera, but by choosing the right apps — out of about 6,500 — your photos can be improved.
articles.abstract: A cellphone is obviously not the best camera, but by choosing the right apps — out of about 6,500 — your photos can be improved.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The best camera,” the saying goes, “is the one you have with you.”

articles.headline: A Japanese Plant Struggles to Produce a Critical Auto Part
articles.snippet: Lack of chips from one plant is a reason auto production has slowed in Japan, the United States and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Lack of chips from one plant is a reason auto production has slowed in Japan, the United States and elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: HITACHINAKA, Japan — A modern car is a computer on wheels. The window openers, the dashboard navigation maps, the fuel injectors — these and many other operations are controlled by some of the 100 or so electronic systems in a typical car.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: With Deal, J.&J. Tries to Change Discussion
articles.snippet: In announcing on Wednesday Johnson & Johnson’s biggest acquisition ever, the company’s chief executive tried to pivot from a year of manufacturing lapses, product recalls and a disappointing share price.
articles.abstract: In announcing on Wednesday Johnson & Johnson’s biggest acquisition ever, the company’s chief executive tried to pivot from a year of manufacturing lapses, product recalls and a disappointing share price.
articles.lead_paragraph: In announcing on Wednesday Johnson & Johnson’s biggest acquisition ever, on the eve of its annual shareholder meeting, the company’s chief executive tried to pivot from a year of manufacturing lapses, product recalls and a disappointing share price.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: A.I.G. to Sue 2 Firms to Recover Some Losses
articles.snippet: American International Group’s lawsuit against ICP Asset Management and Moore Capital makes a case for $350 million in damages as well as recouping a “windfall.”
articles.abstract: American International Group’s lawsuit against ICP Asset Management and Moore Capital makes a case for $350 million in damages as well as recouping a “windfall.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group, the giant insurer rescued by the federal government during the financial crisis, on Thursday will file the first of what could be a series of lawsuits against Wall Street firms, contending that it was the victim of fraud.

articles.headline: Obama’s Pentagon and C.I.A. Picks Show Shift in How U.S. Fights
articles.snippet: The latest evidence of a 10-year shift in American missions is seen with Leon E. Panetta, the intelligence chief, going to the Pentagon, and Gen. David H. Petraeus going to the C.I.A.
articles.abstract: The latest evidence of a 10-year shift in American missions is seen with Leon E. Panetta, the intelligence chief, going to the Pentagon, and Gen. David H. Petraeus going to the C.I.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to send an intelligence chief to the Pentagon and a four-star general to the Central Intelligence Agency is the latest evidence of a significant shift over the past decade in how the United States fights its battles — the blurring of lines between soldiers and spies in secret American missions abroad.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: South Assesses the Toll After a Deadly Barrage of Tornadoes
articles.snippet: Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama said that at least 194 people had died in his state, bringing the number of people killed to at least 280 across six states.
articles.abstract: Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama said that at least 194 people had died in his state, bringing the number of people killed to at least 280 across six states.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — A day after enduring a terrifying bombardment of storms that killed hundreds across the South and spawned tornadoes that razed neighborhoods and even entire towns, people from Texas to Virginia to Georgia searched through rubble for survivors on Thursday and tried to reclaim their own lives.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Kim Severson

articles.headline: U.S. Economic Growth Slows to 1.8% Rate in Quarter
articles.snippet: Higher commodity prices and winter blizzards that shuttered businesses and delayed construction were among the main causes of the slowdown.
articles.abstract: Higher commodity prices and winter blizzards that shuttered businesses and delayed construction were among the main causes of the slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: American economic expansion slowed to a crawl in the first quarter, but economists are hopeful that the setback will be temporary. Total output grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent from January through March, the Commerce Department said Thursday, after expanding at a 3.1 percent pace in the fourth quarter of 2010.
